member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ICollectionReturnHandler
member.summary: Interface for tweaking behavior for methods returning collection types. This can be used to replace collection values returned by a method or property with another test data collection. This interface is returned by the method.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ICollectionReturnHandler.WillReturnCollectionValuesOf(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Swaps a collection returned by a method or property with a collection of test data. Follows a call to .
member.param: The collection to use instead of the replaced collection

remarks.para: This method is used as a completing statement to , and is used to replace the collection in the preceeding statement with the provided collection. This is useful when the code under test uses collection data that is prepared externally and then iterated over. The collection containing this data can be swapped with a test data collection prepared during the test set up and thus remove the dependency on the code populating the collection.

Note: because Typemock Isolator does not currently support faking objects implemented in MsCorLib.dll, the source collection used with WhenCalled() cannot be one implemented in MsCorLib, such as and .

member.exception: If the lambda expression provided in Isolate.WhenCalled() does not evaluate to an object implementing .

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IDynamicSwapper
member.summary: Interface for performing object to object method call swapping
member.remarks: This interface is returned by calling Isolate.Swap.. Follow it by calling the completing statement.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IDynamicSwapper.WithCallsTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Completes swapping method calls for an object. Is called as a completing statement for Isolate.Swap., and defines the target object to perform swapping on.
member.param: The object whose implementation should be used
member.remarks:
When a method is called on the swapped object, it is replaced with a corresponding implementation (a method with the same signature) on the swapping object. This means that the swapped object will start behaving like the object it was swapped with for all methods they have in common.
When a method is called on the swapped object that does not exist in the target object, it will be called on the original object.
member.exception: If there are no compatible methods to swap between the swapping source and target objects.

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IFaker
member.summary: Interface for specifying fake object creation settings. The interface is typed by the preceeding property.
member.remarks: This interface is returned by the property.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IFaker.Dependencies``1(System.Object[])
member.summary: Returns a new instance of T with all dependencies faked.
member.typeparam: The type to which all dependencies will be faked.
member.param: List of real arguments to pass to constructor
member.returns: A new instance of type T.
member.remarks: To create an instance, where all the dependencies are fake, use Isolate.Fake.Dependencies. When the Type is created the longest constructor of T is called with fakes passed as arguments. if a list of constructorArguments is passed, these will be passed in the correct position (matched by type) to the constructor. All primitives are initialized to their base value, as well as structs. Strings are passed empty.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IFaker.Instance``1(TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Members)
member.summary: Overloaded. Returns a fake instance of type T, and allows to set the behavior of how the fake object is created.
member.typeparam: The type of the fake instance to be created.
member.param:
Can be one of the following values:
Members ValueDescription
Members.MustSpecifyReturnValues All void calls are ignored. Unless using on methods that return values and properties, they will throw a .
Members.ReturnNulls All void calls are ignored. Unless using on methods that return values and properties, they will return null values (or zero for value types).
Members.CallOriginal All methods are called. Use to change this behavior.
Members.ReturnRecursiveFakes Default. All void calls are ignored. When calling the fake's methods returning values or properties, they will return a fake value, which presents this behavior recursively. Any deep call will never return a Null value.
member.returns: A fake instance of Type T.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IFaker.StaticConstructor``1
member.summary: Overloaded. Fake future calls to static constructors of the given type.
member.typeparam: The type for which to fake static constructor calls
member.exception: Thown if the static constructor for the provided type has already been called, if an instance fake of the type has already been created or if FakeStaticConstructors has already been called for it.
member.remarks: This overload for FakeStaticConstructor receives a generic parameter. Because static classes cannot be instantiated, they also cannot be used as generic type parameters. In order to fake the static constructors for a static class, use the non generic overload which receives a Type parameter.

member.exception: Thrown if the static constructor for the provided type has already been called, if an instance fake of the type has already been created or if FakeStaticConstructors has already been called for it.
member.remarks: This overload for FakeStaticConstructor receives a Type parameter which represents the class to fake static constructors for, and should be used when faking constructors for static classes. For other non-static classes it is generally recommended to use the generic overload , which receives the class as a generic type argument.

Can be one of the following values:
Members ValueDescription
Members.MustSpecifyReturnValues All void calls are ignored. Unless using on methods that return values and properties, they will throw a .

ConstructorWillBe ValueDescription

ConstructorWillBe.Called Execute Constructor when creating the fake object

The type of the base class who's constructor will be ignored.
The parameters to pass to a specific constructor.

Thrown if faking an interface - to fake an interface use an overload that does not define base class behavior
Thrown if the type being faked does not inherit from
Thrown if there is no constructor that will take the argument set defined in

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.INonPublicMethodBehaviorNoArgs.ReturnRecursiveFake``1
member.summary: Specify that the intercepted method will return a recursive fake of a defined reference type. The real implementation will not be executed.
member.typeparam: Type of the recursive fake to return
member.remarks:
ReturnRecursiveFake<T>() is a completing statement for . It is similar to using the behavior setting when creating fake objects with , but applies only to a single method.
Use ReturnRecursiveFake<T>() on a method to fake out calls to the method and any call chains beginning with it. When ReturnRecursiveFake<T>() is called on a method returning an object, a fake object of type will be returned. That fake object in turn will return fake values for any method calls. ReturnRecursiveFake<T>() on a method returning a value type will set the method to return the default value of that type.
member.returns: The fake object that will be returned. WhenCalled should be used on this object to setup specific behavior.

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IPublicNonVoidRootMethodHandler`1
member.summary: Interface for specifying behavior for intercepted calls on public methods returning values. The interface is returned by the method.
member.remarks: This interface allow tweaking the behavior of public methods that has return values.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IPublicNonVoidRootMethodHandler`1.ReturnRecursiveFake
member.summary: Specify that the intercepted method will return a recursive fake. The real implementation will not be executed.
member.remarks:
ReturnRecursiveFake() is a completing statement for . It is similar to using the behavior setting when creating fake objects with , but applies only to a single method.
Use ReturnRecursiveFake() on a method to fake out calls to the method and any call chains beginning with it. When ReturnRecursiveFake() is called on a method returning an object, a fake object will be returned. That fake object in turn will return fake values for any method calls. ReturnRecursiveFake() on a method returning a value type will set the method to return the default value of that type.
When ReturnRecursiveFake() is used on methods whose returned value is a collection in mscorlib (only collections that implement IEnumerable and have default constructor) then a new initialized collection is returned.
member.returns: The fake object that will be returned. WhenCalled should be used on this object to setup specific behavior.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.IPublicNonVoidRootMethodHandler`1.WithExactArguments
member.summary: Specifies that the behavior will only be set on method calls with the exact arguments.

remarks.para: WithExactArguments() is a completing statement for .

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ISwapper
member.summary: Interface used for swapping between object method calls and collection values.
member.remarks: This interface is returned by the Isolate. property.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ISwapper.NextInstance``1
member.summary: Return a swapping object, in order to swap a future instance of type T with an existing fake object.
member.remarks: Because of the nature of fluent interface, you need to use NextInstance with its proceeding method
member.note: The constructor behavior of the next instance will follow the constructor behavior of the swapped instance. If it is a real object it will be called, if it is a fake it will follow the fakes behavior
member.typeparam: Type of instance to swap.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ISwapper.AllInstances``1
member.summary: Return a swapping object, in order to swap all past and future instance of type T with an existing fake object. Use this method to set the same behavior on all instances of the same type.
member.remarks: Because of the nature of fluent interface, you need to use AllInstances with its proceeding methods or
member.note: The constructor behavior of the next instances will follow the constructor behavior of the swapped instance. If it is a real object it will be called, if it is a fake it will follow the fakes behavior
member.typeparam: Type of instances to swap.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Fluent.ISwapper.CallsOn(System.Object)
member.summary: Enables swapping one object's implementation with another. Followed by the completing statement .
member.param: The object to swap implementation for
member.remarks: When a method is called on the swapped object, it is replaced with a corresponding implementation (a method with the same signature) on the swapping object. This means that the swapped object will start behaving like the object it was swapped with for all methods they have in common.

member.summary: Returns faked objects that where created using Isolate. and Isolate..
member.param: a fake instance
member.returns: An array of instances that are controlled by the fake

member.summary: Overloaded. Returns the number of times a method was called.
member.param: A method in the form of a Lambda Expression that we want to count the calls on.
member.exception: Thrown if there was no behavior set on the object before.
member.remarks: The count is regardless of arguments, and can work on both instance and static methods. It works also on properties and indexers.

member.remarks: This can also be a chain of methods. In that case, the verification is on the entire chain, and not part of it. When arguments are specified, they are ignored in the verification.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.Isolate.CleanUp
member.summary: CleanUp should be called at the end of a test. It can be substituted with the . The method cleans all the mockes the have been created by the test.

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.IsolatedAttribute
member.summary: Used to clean up the defined expectations. This attribute can't be inherited.
member.remarks: Any method marks with this attribute will clean all set expectation after the test is done. A marked class will do this for any test defined in it. The attribute can be replaced with the method.

example.code: < TestFixture >_ < Isolated >_ Public class TestClass < Test >_ Public Sub MyTest1() ' the test code End Sub End Class

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.IsolatedAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: IsolatedAttribute constructor. Defines the DesignMode property to be the default Pragmatic mode.

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.IsolatedAttribute.#ctor(TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.DesignMode)
member.summary: IsolatedAttribute constructor. Let's you specify the DesignMode to override the default Pragmatic mode for either the assmebly, class or test scope.
member.param:
Can be either of the following:
Pragmatic. The default Pragmatic mode allows faking any type and method, including sealed, static or private.
InterfaceOnly. This mode allows faking only abstract or interface types, and public non-virtual methods. Otherwise it throws a DesignModeException.

member.name: P:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.IsolatedAttribute.Design
member.summary: This property defines the design mode for either an assembly, class or a test method scope.
member.value:
By default, Isolators design mode is Pragmatic. In Pragmatic design mode, you can fake any method in any class, including static, sealed or private. In InterfaceOnly design mode, only virtual methods can be faked. Use the DesignMode property explicitly on either assembly, class or a test to override the default, or a higher level specification. For example, you can specify DesignMode.InterfaceOnly in the assembly level, but specify DesignMode.Pragmatic for a specific test.
The property can be set to one of the following values:
Pragmatic. The default Pragmatic mode allows faking any type and method, including sealed, static or private.
InterfaceOnly. This mode allows faking only abstract or interface types, and public non-virtual methods. Otherwise it throws a Typemock.DesignModeException.

example.code: < TestFixture >_ < Isolated (Design := DesignMode.InterfaceOnly) >_ Public class TestClass < Test >_ Public Sub MyTest1() ' the test code End Sub End Class

member.name: M:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.IsolatedAttribute.Execute
member.summary: Called by the framework instead of the original method. This will run the original method and afterwards clear the MockManager.
member.returns: the result of the original method

member.name: T:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.DesignMode
member.summary:
The two different design modes available for mocking:
Pragmatic. The default Pragmatic mode allows faking any type and method, including sealed, static or private.
InterfaceOnly. This mode allows faking only abstract or interface types, and public non-virtual methods. Otherwise it throws a Typemock.DesignModeException.

member.name: F:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.DesignMode.Pragmatic
member.summary: The default Pragmatic mode allows faking any type and method, including sealed, static or private.

member.name: F:TypeMock.ArrangeActAssert.DesignMode.InterfaceOnly
member.summary: This mode allows faking only abstract or interface types, and public non-virtual methods. Otherwise it throws a Typemock.DesignModeException.

member.name: M:TypeMock.RunnerUtils.GetOriginalPath(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Find Original Path of Assembly while in test.
member.remarks: Typemock Smart Runner, copies all assemblies to a shadow copy in order to allow developers to continue to build while the tests are run. This is a helper method to reach original location
member.param: An Assembly that is part of the test

member.name: T:TypeMock.DontRunAttribute
member.summary: TypemockRunnerAttribute signals Isolator automatic runner not to run the decorated method or class automatically
member.remarks: If the test assembly doesn't have a reference to Isolator, it can be added a new attirbute with the same name and the runner will treat it the same way as it was decorated with Typemock DontRun attirubte.
